awd_titl_txt: EAGER Germination: Project Confluence: Engineering and Science to Address Community Needs
awd_abstract_narration:
Many communities across the US face persistent environmental and energy challenges, particularly those who have high proportions of minority or socioeconomically disadvantaged individuals. Community groups may have limited access to engineering and scientific expertise that could help their efforts to address these challenges. This award to Arizona State University will fund an integrated set of efforts to build the skills, resources, and knowledge of engineering and science academic researchers to enable them to conduct research and development (R&D) in support of underserved communities. A key goal of the research is to test whether collaboration with community groups increases the ability of academics to formulate societally impactful research questions. Importantly, underserved communities stand to derive benefit through having academic researchers work with them to identify and address critical questions for their communities.

This project will create approaches and resources for establishing interactions between engineers and scientists and underserved communities with the goal of identifying research needs. Primers and resources on effective collaboration with community groups will be developed and incorporated into an online knowledge-sharing and collaboration platform. In parallel, collaborative technological and scientific needs assessments (CNAs) will be conducted involving both academic researchers and community groups. Importantly, the structure of these CNAs is designed to emphasize community assets and avoid simply focusing on problems or deficits in the community. The CNAs are anticipated to lead to the creation of R&D roadmaps which address important environmental and energy challenges faced by underserved communities, and which can be leveraged for subsequent collaborative work. An important corollary goal will be to determine whether this process impacts the ability of academic researchers to germinate transformative research ideas that address important societal challenges. Self-efficacy of researchers with respect to this question will be assessed through pre- and post-CNA surveys that use a modified version of the Engineering Professional Responsibility Assessment (EPRA) expanded to include the work of scientists. Additionally, empirical testing of question formulation capacity and question value will focus on analysis of responses to a prototype R&D road-map related to community group needs. Positive outcomes in this study would lay the foundation for scaling on a national level, particularly given the planned establishment of an online platform for communicating resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Conceptual learning and outcomes

Our goal for this proposal was to understand how collaborating with community groups increases the ability of academics to formulate societally impactful research questions.  In an ever-changing landscape of environmental, climate, and energy challenges, our research unfolded at a specific moment in time, and thus, based on the nature of the community groups that participated and the engineering/scientific/technical challenges they identified, "doing [societally impactful] things" more accurately captured collaborative work than "[societally impactful] research." 

On reflection, the framing we created for Project Confluence assumed the nature of science that emulated the model that knowledge needed to be created to address the technical challenges community groups identified.  We asked a research question about research questions. This is likely due to our own academic backgrounds in aerospace engineering and environmental anthropology. A hypothesis might have been a better approach to the study of our intervention: Collaboration between academics and community groups changes the way research questions are formulated.

If we had tested this hypothesis by studying the collaborations found in Project Confluence, we would have rejected the null. Most likely we would have wanted to study more collaborations to try to understand under what conditions the null is true and why that is.  We say this because as the collaborations unfolded, we realized that research questions were not necessarily important to what community groups were hoping to achieve, doing things was.  We now know more about how individuals experience collaboration through the lens of conceptualizing doing things, and that there are still diverse avenues that need to be explored.

That said, the open-ended approach led us to discover that collaboration can be about conceptualizing doing things, providing us with a matrix of possibilities for collaborations to consider along a spectrum of implementation and theorization. Of course, we could not have known this without going through the process of conducting this study. Moreover, we found that research questions could still become important at different stages of a collaboration. The process of doing things opened space to conceptualize new questions that had yet to be asked within the collaborations.  Thus, collaboration can challenge our assumptions of how science operates.  The idealized format of conceptualizing research questions, data collection and analysis and formulating conclusions that serves the knowledge for the sake of knowledge model of science, can look very different than the way science operates within a collaboration that aims to address issues of environmental injustice.  This is an important lesson for scientists, engineers, and academics who want to conduct societally impactful work in collaboration with community groups. 

Regardless, we have verified, particularly in the geographic location the study was based in—the metropolitan Phoenix area—that community groups do indeed see immense value in collaborating with scientists, engineers, and academics. 

Methodological learning and outcomes

Project Confluence has leveraged the benefits of the university-managed research model [UMRM] (i.e. access to research grants, interdisciplinary networking) to support the design of community-owned and managed research [COMR] projects.  The work conducted under this grant was a case study to explore the experiences of participants within this hybrid research model project. 

We learned that the flexibility we provided to participants presented its own challenges.  For those interested in designing and executing a project similar to ours, providing the right amount of structure is essential.  Since our work largely unfolded in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, meetings between participants were largely held virtually.  But all participants agreed that the collaborations would have been more successful if meetings were in-person.  Participants also suggested it would be interesting how the different teams that were created to focus on different projects could learn from each other, or in other words, “how collaborations could collaborate.”

Initial outcomes on the platform

In building and launching the Project Confluence matchmaking platform (www.projectconfluence.org), the design of which was shaped by our collaboration-related learnings above, and in the initial phases of marketing it, we have found genuine interest among engineers, scientists, and academics for its utility in connecting with community groups to do societally impactful technical work.
